title: New wave of austerity cuts ahead as Tories order departments to model "savings" of up to 6%
text:
New wave of austerity cuts ahead as Tories order departments to model "savings" of up to 6% Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell fumed: "It is now beyond doubt that Hammond represents more of the same Tory austerity" Share Comments By Dan Bloom 09:38, 28 FEB 2017 Updated 09:48, 28 FEB 2017 News Theresa May's chiefs have ordered departments to model cuts of up to 6% (Photo: REUTERS) A new wave of austerity cuts is on the horizon after Tory ministers ordered Whitehall departments to draw up "savings" of up to 6%.
The scenarios are being modelled as part of an "efficiency review" announced last year to shave £3.5bn off the government's bills by 2020.
Chief Treasury Secretary David Gauke wrote to departments yesterday just a week before Chancellor Philip Hammond 's 2017 Budget.
Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said: "It is now beyond doubt that Hammond represents more of the same Tory austerity.
"Sneaking out an announcement asking departments to model cuts of 3% and 6% for 2019/20 is no way to manage public spending.
Read More Councils warn of drastic cuts after Tories slip out 'hugely disappointing' funding deal "Hammond urgently needs to explain why this announcement was made in the way it was and why, after seven years of failed austerity, he thinks more of the same will now work."
Shadow Chancellor John McDonnell said the announcement had been "sneaked out" (Photo: Jack Taylor) Savings in local government will be used to help meet pressures in over-stretched social care services, the Treasury said.
Yet this flies in the face of councils' repeated claims that they cannot make more savings without cutting local services.
Last week the Tory head of the Local Government Association (LGA) warned leisure centres and libraries may be slashed if a £5.8bn gap is not plugged by 2020.
NHS and school budgets, defence and overseas aid will not be affected by the latest assault, the Treasury said.
But that leaves the burden to fall more heavily on areas like the Department for Communities and Local Government, Home Office and Work and Pensions.
Treasury minister David Gauke said: "We are committed to a modern, high-quality public sector that delivers the services people need in the most efficient way possible.
"There has been considerable progress, but there is further to go and the whole of Government is working together to consider how we can live within our means while delivering maximum value for every pound of taxpayers' money."
